dic.name: Chromatic Number
dic.definition: The chromatic number of a graph Ɇ is the smallest number of colors needed to color the vertices of $G$ so that no two adjacent vertices share the same color, denoted by $chi(G)$.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Number of vertices
dic.definition: Number of vertices
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Number of Edges
dic.definition: Number of Edges
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Clique Number
dic.definition: The clique number $omega(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the number of vertices in a maximum clique in $G$.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Independence Number
dic.definition: The independence number of a graph $G$ is the number of vertices in a maximum independent set in G.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Domination Number
dic.definition: The domination number is the number of vertices in a smallest dominating set for $G$. A dominating set for a graph $G=(V, E)$ is a subset $D$ of $V$ such that every vertex not in $D$ is adjacent to at least one member of $D$.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Total Domination Number
dic.definition: The total domination number $$gamma_t$$ of a graph is the size of a smallest total dominating set, where a total dominating set is a set of vertices of the graph such that all vertices (including those in the set itself) have a neighbor in the set. Total dominating numbers are defined only for graphs having no isolated vertex
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Connected Domination Number
dic.definition: The connected domination number of a connected graph $G$, denoted $d(G)$, is the size of a minimum connected dominating set of a graph $G$. A connected dominating set in a connected graph $G$ is a dominating set in $G$ whose vertices induce a connected subgraph
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Matching Number
dic.definition: The matching number $u(G)$ of graph $G$, sometimes known as the edge independence number, is the size of a maximum independent edge set.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Vertex Connectivity
dic.definition: The vertex connectivity $kappa(G)$ of a graph $G$, also called "point connectivity" or simply "connectivity," is the minimum size of a vertex cut, i.e., a vertex subset $Ssubset V(G)$ such that $G-S$ is disconnected or has only one vertex.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Edge Connectivity
dic.definition: The minimum number of edges $lambda(G)$ whose deletion from a graph $G$ disconnects $G$, also called the line connectivity.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Number of componnents
dic.definition: It's the number of maximals componnents in the graph
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Degree regularity
dic.definition: It's the number of distinct values in the sequence of degrees of the graph.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Maximum Degree
dic.definition: It's the number of distinct values in the sequence of degrees of the graph.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Minimum Degree
dic.definition: Minimum Degree
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Average Degree
dic.definition: Average Degree
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Vertex Cover Number
dic.definition: It's the size of a minimum vertex cover, denoted by $tau(G)$. A vertex cover (or node cover) of a graph is a set of vertices that includes at least one endpoint of every edge of the graph.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Diameter
dic.definition: It's the greatest distance between any pair of vertices.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Radius
dic.definition: The radius r of a graph is the minimum eccentricity of any vertex. The eccentricity of a vertex $v$ is the greatest distance between v and any other vertex.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Largest A-eigenvalue
dic.definition: It's the largest eigenvalue of adjacency matrix.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Largest L-eigenvalue
dic.definition: It's the largest eigenvalue of Laplacian matrix, this is $L=D-A$, where D is the degree matrix and A is the adjacency matrix of the graph.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Largest Q-eigenvalue
dic.definition: It's the largest eigenvalue of Signless Laplacian matrix. Given a simple graph G with n vertices, its Signless Laplacian matrix is Q=D+A, where D is the degree matrix and A is the adjacency matrix of the graph.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Largest D-eigenvalue
dic.definition: It's the largest eigenvalue of graph distance matrix. This matrix is the square where each entry (i,j) represents the distance between the vertices i and j.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Algebraic Connectivity
dic.definition: It's the second-smallest eigenvalue (counting multiple eigenvalues separately) of the Laplacian matrix of G. This is L=D-A, where D is the degree matrix and A is the adjacency matrix of the graph.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Wiener Index
dic.definition: The Wiener index (or the "path number") is a graph index defined for a graph on $n$ nodes by $W=frac{1}{2}sum_{i=1}^{n} sum_{j=1}^{n}d(i,j)$, where $d(i,j)$ is the graph distance matrix, with the distance between the vertices $i$ and $j$.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Estrada Index
dic.definition: It's a graph index defined for a graph on $n$ nodes by $EE(G)=sum _{j=1}^{n}e^{lambda _{j}, where $lambda_i$ is the eigenvalue of adjancecy matrix.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Nullity
dic.definition: In the matrix theory of graphs, the nullity of the graph is the nullity of the adjacency matrix $A$ of the graph. The nullity of $A$ is given by $n âˆ’ r$ where, $r$ is the rank of the adjacency matrix.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Number spanning trees
dic.definition: The number $t(G)$ of spanning trees of a connected graph $G$. A spanning tree $T$ of an undirected graph $G$ is a subgraph that is a tree which includes all of the vertices of $G$. This invariant can be obtained from Kirchhoff's theorem.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Density
dic.definition: It's the number $den(G)=frac{2m}{n(n-1)}$, where $m$ and $n$ are the number of edges and nodes, in order. The density is 0 for a graph without edges and 1 for a complete graph.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Planar
dic.definition: It's a graph that can be embedded in the plane, i.e., it can be drawn on the plane in such a way that its edges intersect only at their endpoints.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Connected
dic.definition: There is a path from any point to any other point in the graph.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Biconnected
dic.definition: A graph is biconnected if, and only if, it cannot be disconnected by removing only one node (and all edges incident on that node).
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Bipartite
dic.definition: It's a graph whose vertices can be divided into two disjoint and independent sets $U$ and $V$ such that every edge connects a vertex in $U$ to one in $V$.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Eulerian
dic.definition: It's a graph that has an Eulerian cycle. An Eulerian cycle (Eulerian circuit or Euler tour) in an undirected graph is a cycle that uses each edge exactly once..
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Chordal
dic.definition: It's one in which all induced cycle in the graph should have exactly three vertices.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Triangle-free
dic.definition: It's a graph in which no three vertices form a triangle of edges.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Regular graph
dic.definition: It's a graph where each vertex has the same number of neighbors; i.e. every vertex has the same degree
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: k-regular graph
dic.definition: It's a regular graph with vertices of degree $k$.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Some M -eigenvalue integer
dic.definition: Checks if there is an integer M-eigenvalue, where $M=A, L, Q or D$.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: M-integral
dic.definition: Checks if all M-eigenvalues are integer, where $M=A, L, Q or D$.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Largest M-eigenvalue is integer
dic.definition: Checks whether the largest M-eigenvalue is an integer, where $M=A, L, Q or D$.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Complement
dic.definition: The complement of a graph G is a graph H on the same vertices such that two distinct vertices of H are adjacent if and only if they are not adjacent in G.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Line graph
dic.definition: The line graph of an undirected graph $G$ is another graph $ell(G)$ that represents the adjacencies between edges of $G$. $ell(G)$ is constructed in the following way: for each edge in $G$, make a vertex in $ell(G)$; for every two edges in $G$ that have a vertex in common, make an edge between their corresponding vertices in $ell(G)$.
dic.usage: For filtering write the X code in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can mark it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph
